msItem.textLang: Latin written in Latin script with some Insular Celtic personal names

support.p: Rejected monument Dyfed Archaeological Trust Historic Environment Record: 1826 Llandysul Stone
support.note: Described by (Edwards 2007, 159) as Medium-grained, quartz-cemented, grey (10YR 6/1 when weathered) sandstone

supportDesc.condition: Edwards (2007, 159) notes that one end of the monument is missing, together with the ends of the first and third lines of the roman-letter inscription. The rest of the inscription is worn but clear. Macalister (1945, 335) claims to have detected the tips of ogham scores on the stone, however, there is no ogham visible on the stone; the only observable inscription is entirely in the roman script.

layoutDesc.layout: According to Macalister (1945, 335), there were traces of an ogham inscription on the lower margin of the stone. The roman-letter inscription consists of three lines which may have originally read horizontally or vertically.

handDesc.handNote: The Latin inscription is lightly punched and consists of capitals with miniscule H. The R's have short diagonal strokes which veer towards the horizontal and that in line 1 has an open loop; F is cursive and conjoined with I, which is small; A has an angle-bar; B has separate loops; the first vertical stroke of the H has been extended downwards (Edwards 2007, 159-161).

origin.origPlace: Llandysul, Cardiganshire (Ceredigion), Wales 52.041192, -4.306581 National Grid Reference: SN 419 406

history.provenance: First mentioned in a letter from David Evans to Edward Lhuyd dated 30 January 1702/1703, the stone was recorded as being built into the churchyard wall and was already fragmentary (Edwards 2007, 159).
Inside the church, built into the north wall of the west tower (SN 4188 4068).

app.note: Traces of ogam inscription were first noted by Macalister in 1922 and again in 1945. However, the ogham inscription described by Macalister was later dismissed by McManus (1991, 68). According to Edwards (2007, 159), there is no evidence that an ogham inscription ever existed.

Whether the roman-letter inscription was originally horizontal or vertical is uncertain. Edwards (2007, 159) contends that the inscription was most likely read vertically downwards because it consists of a variation of the 'X son of Y' formula in this format. Despite its incomplete state, the inscription exhibits several letter forms, notably miniscule H, which suggest it is typologically late in the series (Edwards 2007, 161).

div.p: According to Sims-Williams (Edwards 2007, 161), VELVOR can be compared with VELVE, VELVALIS and VELVINNA; the first element may be the preform of W. gwelw 'pale'. Sims-Williams (Edwards 2007, 161), therefore, suggests VELVOR[IA] as a sensible reconstruction, with -o-ria being the feminine Latinized equivalent of Celtic -o-rix. The second name in the inscription, BROHO, Sims-Williams (Edwards 2007, 161) maintains is no doubt the same Welsh name as BROHOMAGLI and BROHCMAIL, W. Brochfael *Brokkomaglos 'badger prince'. The inscription is one of a small group commemorating women, in this case using filia 'daughter' in the nominative case.
